Introduction

Intraductal papillomas (

figure 1
) are benign papillary tumors arising from the lining of breast ducts.  They are the most common cause of unilateral, bloody nipple discharge.

Pathophysiology



Intraductal papillomas are benign lesions that arise from the lining of the breast ducts.  They are papillary projections composed of epithelial and myoepithelial cells that line a fibrovascular stalk (

image 1
).  Twisting of the stalk causes intraluminal bleeding with subsequent bloody nipple discharge.



Intraductal papillomas are usually small (â‰¤1 cm) and may be solitary or multiple.  They most often occur near the areola within the central breast.  Because of their size and location, they are often not palpable clinically.  On occasion, there may be cellular atypia (ie, atypical hyperplasia) or even ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) within the papilloma.

Risk factors



  • Age 35-55
  • Family history of breast cancer
  • Estrogen exposure (oral contraceptive pills, menopausal hormone therapy)

Clinical presentation



The most common presentation is with pathologic nipple discharge (ie, bloody or serosanguineous, unilateral).  Most intraductal papillomas present without a palpable lump or mass, but occasionally, a small mass located behind the areola may be felt.  Rarely, pain or breast discomfort is a presenting symptom.  Some intraductal papillomas are completely asymptomatic and found incidentally on routine imaging.

Diagnosis



A definitive diagnosis is made with histopathologic examination on biopsied specimens (eg, core needle biopsy).  However, a full evaluation is required in any patient with pathologic nipple discharge because breast malignancy may also present in a similar fashion (ie, malignant tumor growth within the lactiferous duct system).  This involves:



  • Clinical breast examination may reveal a subareolar lump or mass.
  • Age-based imaging (
    figure 2
    ) with ultrasonography (<30), mammography (â‰¥30), or both (â‰¥40) is performed.  Because of the small size of most intraductal papillomas, imaging may be normal and MRI of the breast may be required for greater sensitivity.
  • Core needle biopsy is the preferred method for obtaining a tissue sample for histologic examination.

Differential diagnosis



  • Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS):  refers to a mixed group of neoplasms confined to the breast duct and lobules with dystrophic calcifications.  DCIS may be associated with a palpable lump or pathologic nipple discharge; however, most are found as abnormal calcifications on screening mammography.  Intraductal papillomas are less likely to be identified on mammography (due to small intraductal size) and are not associated with calcifications.
  • Mammary duct ectasia:  a benign condition characterized by dilated subareolar milk ducts, often presents with sticky, green/black nipple discharge that can be expressed with palpation.  It is commonly associated with a palpable subareolar mass.  Imaging shows dilated tubular structures.
  • Breast abscess (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
    ):  a localized infection within the breast tissue containing purulent fluid.  Most commonly, breast abscesses follow severe lactational mastitis but can form after other conditions (periductal mastitis).  Breast abscesses present with a fluctuant mass, erythema, swelling, systemic symptoms (fever), and, at times, purulent nipple discharge (depending on the abscess location).
  • Phyllodes tumor:  a fibroepithelial tumor that often experiences rapid growth, leading to a multinodular mass that does not often present with nipple discharge.  Histology shows a leaf-like proliferation of stromal tissue on core needle biopsy.
  • Fibroadenoma (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
    ):  presents as a solitary, well-circumscribed, mobile benign breast mass, most often located in the upper outer quadrant of the breast.  It does not cause nipple discharge.

Management



Asymptomatic (ie, incidentally found), small intraductal papillomas with no evidence of cellular atypia on core needle biopsy may be managed with observation and regular follow-up.  Surgical excision is recommended when the intraductal papilloma has bothersome symptoms (eg, bloody nipple discharge), is associated with a palpable mass, or has atypia on core needle biopsy.

Prognosis



Intraductal papillomas are benign lesions with an excellent prognosis following appropriate management.  The risk for breast cancer is slightly increased in women with multiple papillomas or atypical hyperplasia; therefore, regular monitoring and follow-up are necessary to ensure early detection of potential malignancies.

Summary



Intraductal papillomas (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
) are benign papillary tumors arising from the lining of breast ducts.  They are the most common cause of unilateral, bloody nipple discharge.  They require age-based imaging and core needle biopsy for diagnosis, and management is most often with surgical excision.
